Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Courts evaluate modification requests under the “best interests of the child” standard.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel concerns the constitutional limits on state interference with a fit parent’s decisions in the context of nonparent (grandparent) visitation. The opinion repeatedly criticizes Washington’s statute for using a bare “best interests of the child” standard without giving special weight to the parent’s decision, and it explicitly declines to define the constitutional standard for such cases. It does not hold that courts should or do evaluate ‘modification requests’ (or visitation requests generally) under a generic best‑interests standard; if anything, it questions reliance on that standard alone in this context.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The Washington nonparental visitation statute is breathtakingly broad. According to the statute's text, ‘[a]ny person may petition the court for visitation rights at any time,’ and the court may grant such visitation rights whenever ‘visitation may serve the best interest of the child.’ … Once the visitation petition has been filed in court … § 26.10.160(3) contains no requirement that a court accord the parent's decision any presumption of validity or any weight whatsoever. Instead, the Washington statute places the best-interest determination solely in the hands of the judge.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a7\u00a751A.proposition: Massachusetts statutory authorities concerning mandatory reporting and investigation of suspected child abuse and neglect (Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, §§51A–51B) inform the Court’s responsibility to consider safety concerns and may warrant a 51A investigation where abuse or neglect is suspected.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has authority to issue temporary and permanent orders altering visitation, imposing supervision, excluding third parties, and ordering such other relief as necessary to protect the child’s welfare pending a full hearing.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C.proposition: Courts evaluate modification requests under the “best interests of the child” standard.

King v. King, 409 Mass. 197 (1991).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the safety and well‑being of the child may justify limiting or conditioning visitation where exposure to another adult presents a risk of harm.

Belsito v. Belsito, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Belsito v. Belsito, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1993)
Belsito v. Belsito, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the safety and well‑being of the child may justify limiting or conditioning visitation where exposure to another adult presents a risk of harm.
Belsito v. Belsito, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Belsito v. Belsito concerns consent, probable cause, and exigent circumstances in the context of a police entry and a motion to suppress in a criminal matter. It does not address child custody, visitation, or limitations based on exposure to another adult. Therefore, this opinion does not support the proposition about conditioning visitation for a child’s safety and well‑being.
Belsito v. Belsito, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt: "It is, however, unnecessary in my view to determine whether the evidence at trial contradicted the evidence at the suppression hearing which supported the conclusion that the second entry was consensual. The trial judge’s refusal to reconsider the pretrial motion to suppress is supported on the ground briefly mentioned in note 6 of the majority opinion, namely that the police had probable cause to make the second entry into the apartment and that the circumstances were exigent."

Desrosiers v. Desrosiers, 37 Mass. App..raw_text: Desrosiers v. Desrosiers, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 570 (1994)
Desrosiers v. Desrosiers, 37 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that the safety and well‑being of the child may justify limiting or conditioning visitation where exposure to another adult presents a risk of harm.
Desrosiers v. Desrosiers, 37 Mass. App..support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about unarmed robbery and joint venture liability; it does not involve family law, child custody, visitation, or the effect of exposure to another adult on a child’s safety or well‑being. Nothing in the holding or reasoning addresses standards for limiting or conditioning visitation based on risks posed by another adult, so it cannot serve as authority for that proposition.
Desrosiers v. Desrosiers, 37 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “A jury in the Superior Court convicted the defendants of unarmed robbery, G. L. c. 265, § 19. … Carr makes several arguments on appeal, principally whether the judge erred in denying his motion for a required finding of not guilty. … Defendant Carr claims that the government failed to present enough evidence for any rational trier of fact to conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that he was a joint venturer in the purse snatching. We agree.” (No discussion of child custody, visitation, or child safety appears in the opinion.)

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).proposition: Courts regularly examine allegations of violence, criminal activity, and domestic disturbances in determining whether to modify visitation. See, e.g., Adoption and custody decisions addressing exposure to violent third parties; see also Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982) (standard for parental rights in serious proceedings).
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Santosky v. Kramer concerns how courts examine allegations of violence, criminal activity, and domestic disturbances in modifying visitation, and characterizes it as setting the standard for parental rights in such serious proceedings. Santosky, however, deals specifically with the due process standard of proof (clear and convincing evidence) required for state-initiated termination of parental rights, not visitation modification or exposure to violent third parties. While it addresses the constitutional protection of parental rights generally, it does not discuss visitation standards or the kinds of factual allegations referenced in the proposition.
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Today we hold that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment demands more than this. Before a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidence.”

In re Marriage of Sinnott, 406 Mass. 89.raw_text: In re Marriage of Sinnott, 406 Mass. 89 (1989)
In re Marriage of Sinnott, 406 Mass. 89.proposition: (Authoritative examples and precedent required in custody modification matters include: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000); Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982); King v. King, 409 Mass. 197 (1991); Belsito v. Belsito, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1993); Desrosiers v. Desrosiers, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 570 (1994); In re Marriage of Sinnott, 406 Mass. 89 (1989) (best interests analysis); Custody of a Minor, 420 Mass. 622 (1995) (examples of custody modification jurisprudence); Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, §§51A–51B (child abuse reporting and investigation); Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (divorce and custody authority); Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (parentage); applicable Probate and Family Court Rules.)
In re Marriage of Sinnott, 406 Mass. 89.support_reasoning: The proposition claims Sinnott as an example of “best interests analysis” and custody modification jurisprudence. This opinion does not conduct any best-interests-of-the-child (or adult child) custody analysis; it deals almost entirely with whether a Connecticut probate order is entitled to full faith and credit in Massachusetts, focusing on jurisdiction and collateral attack on judgments. There is no substantive discussion of custody standards or best-interests factors, so the case does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
In re Marriage of Sinnott, 406 Mass. 89.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude, as did the Massachusetts Probate Court judge, that the Connecticut order is not entitled to full faith and credit in Massachusetts. Therefore, we affirm the order below dismissing the plaintiff’s petition.… A forum State (in this case, Massachusetts) must give full faith and credit to the judgment of a rendering State (here, Connecticut) only when the rendering State had personal and subject matter jurisdiction.”

Custody of a Minor, 420 Mass. 622 (1995).proposition: (Authoritative examples and precedent required in custody modification matters include: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000); Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982); King v. King, 409 Mass. 197 (1991); Belsito v. Belsito, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1993); Desrosiers v. Desrosiers, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 570 (1994); In re Marriage of Sinnott, 406 Mass. 89 (1989) (best interests analysis); Custody of a Minor, 420 Mass. 622 (1995) (examples of custody modification jurisprudence); Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, §§51A–51B (child abuse reporting and investigation); Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (divorce and custody authority); Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (parentage); applicable Probate and Family Court Rules.)
Custody of a Minor, 420 Mass. 622 (1995).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case (postconviction/new trial motions) involving grand jury practice, ineffective assistance, lost evidence, and related issues. It does not concern custody, family law, or custody modification standards, nor does it provide any jurisprudence on custody modification or best-interests analysis. The proposition misidentifies the case: 420 Mass. 622 (1995) here is Commonwealth v. Martinez, not a custody case, so it cannot serve as authority for custody modification jurisprudence.
Custody of a Minor, 420 Mass. 622 (1995).relevant_excerpt: "Each defendant was found guilty of trafficking in cocaine in an amount between 100 and 200 grams and with distribution of cocaine within 1,000 feet of a school. The defendant Martinez was also found guilty of armed assault with intent to murder; assault and battery by means of a dangerous weapon; and unlawfully carrying a firearm... While the defendants’ appeals were pending in the Appeals Court, each defendant... filed a motion for a new trial... We affirm the orders denying the defendants’ motions."

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has authority to issue temporary and permanent orders altering visitation, imposing supervision, excluding third parties, and ordering such other relief as necessary to protect the child’s welfare pending a full hearing.
